title: Dominica declares disaster and appeals for aid after Tropical Storm Erika leaves 20 dead
text:
127 shares 6

The Caribbean island of Dominica has declared disaster status for nine local areas and is appealing for international aid after Tropical Storm Erika left 20 people dead and more than 50 missing in its wake.
Erika whipped the island for more than five hours on Wednesday, bringing strong winds and intense rain that provoked deadly flooding and landslides and destroyed hundreds of homes.
Prime Minister Roosevelt Skerrit said damage from the storm could set the country's development back two decades.

'The extent of the devastation is monumental,' Skerrit told his countrymen. 'It is far worse than expected. We have, in essence, to rebuild Dominica'.
'We are in this together and help is coming your way,' he said, according to CNN .
Rescue teams worked Sunday to reopen roads to remote communities in the island that had been left isolated by the storm.
Skerrit said the towns had been 'cut off from the rest of the country' after the storm made access by road impossible.
Prime Minister Roosevelt Skerrit said damage from the storm could set the country's development back two decades.
Dominica'a Douglas-Charles airport is pictured above covered in debris. It is too badly damaged for planes use. The island's other airport is also closed
On Sunday the government also ordered the evacuation of about 1,000 inhabitants from the small town of Petite-Savanne, fearing new landslides.
Crews were using heavy equipment sent by the governments of Venezuela, Martinique and Guadalupe.

Share this article Share Hundreds of men also worked over the weekend to reopen the country's main airport, where mud and debris impeded operations, Skerrit said.
Roads and buildings on the island of about 70,000 people were smashed apart by flash floods after is received more than 12 inches of rain in less than 10 hours.
This church was ruined by water pulsing through the streets of the capital city of Roseau. Some areas of the island were cut off from rescue workers
Authorities said that in addition to the dead, there were 31 people missing in Dominica on Friday. Above, the village of Coliahut
Forty-six-year-old security guard Peter Julian, who had joined friends after leaving work, returned to find his home on 20 years destroyed.
'I am blessed to be alive. God was not ready for me ... I have lost everything and now have to start all over again,' he said.
Many more people are expected to have died in the village on the island's southern tip.
The storm also triggered mudslides in Haiti, killing at least one person.
Four others died when a truck hit a bus during the downpour.
Tropical Storm Erika dissipated over the mountains of Hispaniola near the north coast of eastern Cuba at 9.30am on Saturday, according to the US National Hurricane Center.
Now considered a tropical rainstorm, Erika is still expect to bring downpours to Florida and Cuba throughout the week, reported AccuWeather .
